description:
Numida meleagris, commonly known as the helmeted guinea fowl or just guinea fowl, is a species of ground-dwelling bird native to Africa. It belongs to the family Numididae, which is a group of landfowl found exclusively on the African continent.

The helmeted guinea fowl is a medium-sized bird, typically measuring between 40-55 cm in length and weighing around 1.3-1.8 kg. It has a distinctive, rounded body with a small head and a unique, bony casque or "helmet" on top of its head. The plumage is predominantly black and white, with a speckled or mottled pattern, giving it a striking appearance.

These birds are known for their social behavior, often living in large flocks and exhibiting a range of vocalizations, including a loud, distinctive "kek-kek-kek" call. They are omnivorous, feeding on a variety of plant matter, insects, and small invertebrates.

Numida meleagris is widely distributed across sub-Saharan Africa, inhabiting a range of habitats, including savannas, grasslands, and scrublands. They play an important ecological role as seed dispersers and pest controllers, and are also valued for their meat and eggs in many African cultures.
